<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i = i + 1;
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));

<<<explanation>>>: You're creating a new dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator() in every iteration of your loop. Try to just use the value of the foreach inside the loop.

Answer:
To get the DPI (dots per inch) of an image in Java, you can use the ImageReader class from the Java 2D API. Here is an example code snippet that demonstrates how to use the ImageReader class to get the DPI of an image:
```
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.IOException;
import javax.imageio.ImageIO;
import javax.imageio.ImageReader;
import javax.imageio.stream.ImageInputStream;

public class ImageDPIReader {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        File imageFile = new File("path/to/image.jpg");
        ImageInputStream imageStream = ImageIO.createImageInputStream(imageFile);
        ImageReader reader = ImageIO.getImageReader(imageStream);
        int width = reader.getWidth(0);
        int height = reader.getHeight(0);
        int numImages = reader.getNumImages(0);
        double dpiX = (double) width / (double) numImages;
        double dpiY = (double) height / (double) numImages;
        System.out.println("DPI X: " + dpiX);
        System.out.println("DPI Y: " + dpiY);
    }
}
```
This code reads the image from the specified file, gets the width, height and number of images in the image, and then calculates the DPI by dividing the width and height by the number of images.

Please note that this code snippet uses the Java 2D API, which is not part of the standard Java library. You need to include the Java 2D API in your project in order to use it.
